author: mvis.79
content: I'm just a 2-bit programmer / lurker here ... probably shouldn't even speak up ... but I think you might want to consider the fact that there seems to be zero infrastructure /wallet / developer / documentation support for 1559 at this point.  I have been searching high and low for the last 3 or 4 days, trying to find out how to submit a 1559 style transaction, and I can find NOTHING!  The main javascript web3 package has no support for 1559.  They only opened a github issue on it a few weeks ago.   Metamask does not support 1559.  They opened a github issue on it 4 days ago.   Etherscan appeared to have no support for 1559 yesterday, although today I noticed they are now supporting the new fields.  Honestly guys, this seems like a pretty strange way to roll out a major new feature.  I wouldn't even *think* about setting a block number for mainnet until all of the above projects are ready, and a whole lot of other as well.

author: ajsutton
content: Old style transactions are still supported even once 1559 is live so it's ok if tools take some more time to update to make it possible/easy to send 1559 transactions.

author: mvis.79
content: <@!340345049063882753>  True, but I saw Peter appealing on twitter for people to test 1559 on ropsten.  How are we supposed to do that when we can't submit new style transactions?

author: mvis.79
content: You are a man of great faith!  ðŸ™‚

author: ajsutton
content: There's been quite a few sent already so it is possible.  I'd have to leave it to others to say how they did it or exactly what the state of all the tools are.

author: mvis.79
content: Oh for sure it is possible ... if you're a deep into the R/D tech or a developer for one of the clients.  But for regular folks like me?  Not so much.

author: mvis.79
content: The json rpc wiki could use some updating for 1559:  https://eth.wiki/json-rpc/API

author: evanvanness
content: in Ethereum, if you see something that needs to be done, try to do it.  ask questions.  write about it.  publish.

author: timbeiko
content: 1. As Adrian said, 1559 is not strictly necessary, so it's fine if not everyone implements it when mainnet upgrades. Protocol upgrades are already a slow process with a lot of inertia, and adding more requirements can make a slow process basically grind to a halt.

author: timbeiko
content: 2. That being said, we obviously do want _some_ support for it. There is no clear line here, but I'm aware of major wallets, infratructure provider, libraries, etc. which are all adding support for 1559 now. If you want to test it as a "2-bit programmer", which I also consider myself, I recommend using Clef by Geth. I was able to figure that out yesterday pretty easily ðŸ™‚

author: timbeiko
content: As for JSON RPC, the updated spec is here: https://github.com/ethereum/eth1.0-specs/tree/master/json-rpc It has the new 1559 APIs

author: timbeiko
content: 3. As <@456226577798135808> said, even if we choose a block tomorrow (absolutely not guaranteed!), it won't be less than 1 month out. We will discuss that on the call tomorrow and see how comfortable the client teams are with doing so. It's very possible we decide to wait a bit more to either have more infra ready/see more testnets upgrade/etc.

author: timbeiko
content: Hope this clears this up a bit!

author: jc6763
content: Any wallets, tools for sending 1559 txs? Any resources to pin so people can find easily?

author: karalabe
content: Geth sends 1559 txs by default if you don't specify a gas price

author: karalabe
content: or you can manually send via setting maxFeePerGas and/or maxPriorityFeePerGas

author: karalabe
content: in the eth_sendTransaction call

author: axic3354
content:
Since EIP-3074 is being discussed on the call, I'd like to share some concern in relation to address space extension: https://notes.ethereum.org/@ipsilon/address-space-extension-issues#4b-EIP-3074

If address space extension is something we want, then we should carefully review it's impact on EIP-3074 (the address recovery part of `AUTH`).

author: mvis.79
content: For some reason, that spec only includes `eth_sendRawTransaction`.   `eth_sendTransaction` seems to be missing, which of course would be the one most helpful in this situation.

author: ravensslayer

author: axic3354
content: <@!555483069038198827> <@!360491619402776577> I totally agree that probability is close to nil today to impersonate a precompile, but there was an argument 5 years ago that it is improbable to impersonate a contract address, yet here we are today discussing this EIP. While we're at changing/fixing this, why not exclude precompiles at the same time for good measure? (But my comment is more driven by spec clarity / expressiveness, as opposed to probability.)

author: timbeiko
content:
**London Updates from ACD**
- It seems like everyone is generally satisfied with the Ropsten fork, but we want to wait and see how Goerli goes to be sure. Once that happens, assuming everything goes smoothly, we can pick a block for mainnet. My suggestion would be `12970000` (Aug. 4th), which is mid-week before the next difficulty bomb period. Again, this **assumes everything goes well on Goerli**. If others have different suggestions, I'm not married to this one. 
- Clients still need to add a few things / fix a few bugs for London, but, again, assuming Goerli goes well, should be able to have a release out by the next ACD call which includes the London mainnet block and all London-related features.

author: timbeiko
content: Other motivation re: waiting for Goerli to upgrade (h/t <@!291925846556540928>) is that we'll see how Eth2 testnets behave with London
